paragraph:
The statistical interpretation of quantum
mechanics
Nobel Lecture, December 11, 1954

The work, for which I have had the honour to be awarded the Nobel Prize
for 1954, contains no discovery of a fresh natural phenomenon, but rather
the basis for a new mode of thought in regard to natural phenomena. This
way of thinking has permeated both experimental and theoretical physics to
such a degree that it hardly seems possible to say anything more about it that
has not been already so often said. However, there are some particular
aspects which I should like to discuss on whatis, for me, such a festive occa-
sion. The first point is this: the work at the Géttingen school, which I
directed at that time (1926-1927), contributed to the solution of an intellec-
tual crisis into which our science had fallen as a result of Planck’s discovery
of the quantum of action in 1900. Today, physics finds itself in a similar
crisis - I do not mean here its entanglement in politics and economics as a
result of the mastery of a new and frightful force of Nature, but I am con-
sidering more the logical and epistemological problems posed by nuclear
physics. Perhaps it is well at such a time to recall what took place earlier in
a similar situation, especially as these events are not without a definite dramat-
ic flavour.

metaphors.Full Sentence: The work, for which I have had the honour to be awarded the Nobel Prize for 1954, contains no discovery of a fresh natural phenomenon, but rather the basis for a new mode of thought in regard to natural phenomena.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: the basis for a new mode of thought
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Discovery is a new mode of thought

metaphors.Full Sentence: Today, physics finds itself in a similar crisis - I do not mean here its entanglement in politics and economics as a result of the mastery of a new and frightful force of Nature, but I am considering more the logical and epistemological problems posed by nuclear physics.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: physics finds itself in a similar crisis
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific problems are crises

metaphors.Full Sentence: I do not mean here its entanglement in politics and economics as a result of the mastery of a new and frightful force of Nature, but I am considering more the logical and epistemological problems posed by nuclear physics.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: its entanglement in politics and economics
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific impact is an entanglement

metaphors.Full Sentence: I do not mean here its entanglement in politics and economics as a result of the mastery of a new and frightful force of Nature, but I am considering more the logical and epistemological problems posed by nuclear physics.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: the mastery of a new and frightful force of Nature
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific discovery is mastery of a force

paragraph:
The second point I wish to make is that when I say that the physicists had
accepted the concepts and mode of thought developed by us at the time, I
am not quite correct. There are some very noteworthy exceptions, partic-
ularly among the very workers who have contributed most to building up
the quantum theory. Planck, himself, belonged to the sceptics until he died.
Einstein, De Broglie, and Schrédinger have unceasingly stressed the unsatis-
factory features of quantum mechanics and called for a return to the con-
cepts of classical, Newtonian physics while proposing ways in which this
could be done without contradicting experimental facts. Such weighty views
cannot be ignored. Niels Bohr has gone to a great deal of trouble to refute
the objections. I, too, have ruminated upon them and believe I can make
some contribution to the clarification of the position. The matter concerns
the borderland between physics and philosophy, and so my physics lecture

metaphors.Full Sentence: There are some very noteworthy exceptions, particularly among the very workers who have contributed most to building up the quantum theory.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: building up the quantum theory
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Developing a scientific theory is like building a structure

metaphors.Full Sentence: I, too, have ruminated upon them and believe I can make some contribution to the clarification of the position.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: clarification of the position
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding a scientific theory is like clarifying a position

metaphors.Full Sentence: The matter concerns the borderland between physics and philosophy, and so my physics lecture
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: the borderland between physics and philosophy
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The intersection of different disciplines is like a borderland

paradoxes.full_sentence: Einstein, De Broglie, and Schrédinger have unceasingly stressed the unsatisfactory features of quantum mechanics and called for a return to the concepts of classical, Newtonian physics while proposing ways in which this could be done without contradicting experimental facts.
paradoxes.short_explanation: The paradox lies in the tension between the desire to return to classical, Newtonian physics and the need to not contradict experimental facts that support quantum mechanics. The two are fundamentally different in their understanding of the universe, with quantum mechanics allowing for phenomena that classical physics cannot explain.

paragraph:
--- Page 2 ---
INTERPRETATION OF QUANTUM MECHANICS 257

will partake of both history and philosophy, for which I must crave your
indulgence.

First of all, I will explain how quantum mechanics and its statistical inter-
pretation arose. At the beginning of the twenties, every physicist, I think,
was convinced that Planck’s quantum hypothesis was correct. According to
this theory energy appears in finite quanta of magnitude hv in oscillatory
processes having a specific frequency v (e.g. in light waves). Countless
experiments could be explained in this way and always gave the same value
of Planck’s constant h. Again, Einstein’s assertion that light quanta have
momentum hv/c (where c is the speed of light) was well supported by exper-
iment (e.g. through the Compton effect). This implied a revival of the
corpuscular theory of light for a certain complex of phenomena. The wave
theory still held good for other processes. Physicists grew accustomed to this
duality and learned how to cope with it to a certain extent.

paradoxes.full_sentence: This implied a revival of the corpuscular theory of light for a certain complex of phenomena. The wave theory still held good for other processes.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the simultaneous acceptance of two conflicting theories of light: the corpuscular theory, which views light as a stream of particles, and the wave theory, which views light as a wave phenomenon. These theories are fundamentally different and yet, according to the author, both are used to explain different phenomena in physics.

paragraph:
In 1913 Niels Bohr had solved the riddle of line spectra by means of the
quantum theory and had thereby explained broadly the amazing stability
of the atoms, the structure of their electronic shells, and the Periodic System
of the elements. For what was to come later, the most important assumption
of his teaching was this: an atomic system cannot exist in all mechanically
possible states, forming a continuum, but in a series of discrete « stationary »
states. In a transition from one to another, the difference in energy E,,-
En is emitted or absorbed as a light quantum home (according to whether
E,,is greater or less than E,). This is an interpretation in terms of energy
of the fundamental law of spectroscopy discovered some years before by
W. Ritz. The situation can be taken in at a glance by writing the energy
levels of the stationary states twice over, horizontally and vertically. This
produces a square array

metaphors.Full sentence: In 1913 Niels Bohr had solved the riddle of line spectra by means of the quantum theory and had thereby explained broadly the amazing stability of the atoms, the structure of their electronic shells, and the Periodic System of the elements.

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Solving a scientific problem is like solving a riddle

metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: forming a continuum
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Atomic states are likened to a continuum

metaphors.Full sentence: In a transition from one to another, the difference in energy E,,- En is emitted or absorbed as a light quantum home (according to whether E,,is greater or less than E,).

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Energy transition is conceptualised as a journey or movement from one 'home' to another

metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: taken in at a glance
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding complex scientific data is like quickly scanning a familiar scene

paradoxes.full_sentence: For what was to come later, the most important assumption of his teaching was this: an atomic system cannot exist in all mechanically possible states, forming a continuum, but in a series of discrete « stationary » states.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the contradiction between the idea of an atomic system existing in all mechanically possible states (suggesting a continuum of states) and the idea of it existing in a series of discrete, or separate, stationary states. This challenges the traditional understanding of mechanics and introduces the quantum concept of discrete energy levels.

paragraph:
in which positions on a diagonal correspond to states, and non-diagonal
positions correspond to transitions.

It was completely clear to Bohr that the law thus formulated is in conflict
with mechanics, and that therefore the use of the energy concept in this

connection is problematical. He based this daring fusion of old and new on
his principle of correspondence. This consists in the obvious requirement that
ordinary classical mechanics must hold to a high degree of approximation
in the limiting case where the numbers of the stationary states, the so-called
quantum numbers, are very large (that is to say, far to the right and to the
lower part in the above array) and the energy changes relatively little from
place to place, in fact practically continuously.

metaphors.Full Sentence: He based this daring fusion of old and new on his principle of correspondence.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: daring fusion of old and new
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Combining different theories is like fusing old and new materials

metaphors.Full Sentence: This consists in the obvious requirement that ordinary classical mechanics must hold to a high degree of approximation in the limiting case where the numbers of the stationary states, the so-called quantum numbers, are very large (that is to say, far to the right and to the lower part in the above array) and the energy changes relatively little from place to place, in fact practically continuously.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: must hold to a high degree of approximation in the limiting case
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Applying scientific principles is like reaching an approximation

metaphors.Full Sentence: This consists in the obvious requirement that ordinary classical mechanics must hold to a high degree of approximation in the limiting case where the numbers of the stationary states, the so-called quantum numbers, are very large (that is to say, far to the right and to the lower part in the above array) and the energy changes relatively little from place to place, in fact practically continuously.

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Changes in energy levels is like movement between physical places

paragraph:
Theoretical physics maintained itself on this concept for the next ten
years. The problem was this: an harmonic oscillation not only has a fre-
quency, but also an intensity. For each transition in the array there must be
a corresponding intensity. The question is how to find this through the
considerations of correspondence? It meant guessing the unknown from the
available information on a known limiting case. Considerable success was
attained by Bohr himself, by Kramers, Sommerfeld, Epstein, and many
others. But the decisive step was again taken by Einstein who, by a fresh
derivation of Planck’s radiation formula, made it transparently clear that the
classical concept of intensity of radiation must be replaced by the statistical
concept of transition probability. To each place in our pattern or array there
belongs (together with the frequency ¥mp = (Ex— Em){h) a definite prob-
ability for the transition coupled with emission or absorption.

metaphors.Full sentence: Theoretical physics maintained itself on this concept for the next ten years.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: Theoretical physics maintained itself on this concept
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The theoretical physics is presented as a structure or an entity that can maintain itself on a concept

metaphors.Full sentence: It meant guessing the unknown from the available information on a known limiting case.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: guessing the unknown
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The unknown is seen as a hidden object that can be guessed or discovered

metaphors.Full sentence: But the decisive step was again taken by Einstein who, by a fresh derivation of Planck’s radiation formula, made it transparently clear that the classical concept of intensity of radiation must be replaced by the statistical concept of transition probability.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: the decisive step was again taken by Einstein
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The progress in scientific understanding is mapped onto a journey where steps are taken

metaphors.Full sentence: But the decisive step was again taken by Einstein who, by a fresh derivation of Planck’s radiation formula, made it transparently clear that the classical concept of intensity of radiation must be replaced by the statistical concept of transition probability.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: made it transparently clear
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding or realization is represented as seeing through a transparent object

paradoxes.full_sentence: The problem was this: an harmonic oscillation not only has a frequency, but also an intensity. For each transition in the array there must be a corresponding intensity. The question is how to find this through the considerations of correspondence?
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the difficulty of determining the intensity of each transition in the array through the considerations of correspondence. The harmonic oscillation has both frequency and intensity, but how to find the intensity for each transition is a paradoxical problem.

paradoxes.full_sentence: But the decisive step was again taken by Einstein who, by a fresh derivation of Planck’s radiation formula, made it transparently clear that the classical concept of intensity of radiation must be replaced by the statistical concept of transition probability.
terms_in_conflict: classical concept of intensity of radiation
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is the conflict between the classical concept of intensity of radiation and the statistical concept of transition probability. Einstein's derivation of Planck’s radiation formula suggests that the former must be replaced by the latter, which contradicts the traditional understanding of radiation intensity.

paragraph:
In Gottingen we also took part in efforts to distil the unknown mechanics
of the atom from the experimental results. The logical difficulty became ever
sharper. Investigations into the scattering and dispersion of light showed that
Einstein’s conception of transition probability as a measure of the strength of
an oscillation did not meet the case, and the idea of an amplitude of oscillation
associated with each transition was indispensable. In this connection, work by
Ladenburg', Kramer’, Heisenberg’, Jordan and me'should be mentioned.
The art of guessing correct formulae, which deviate from the classical for-
mulae, yet contain them as a limiting case according to the correspondence
principle, was brought to a high degree of perfection. A paper of mine,
which introduced, for the first time I think, the expression quantum mechanics
in its title, contains a rather involved formula (still valid today) for the recip-
rocal disturbance of atomic systems.

metaphors.Full Sentence: In Gottingen we also took part in efforts to distil the unknown mechanics of the atom from the experimental results.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: distil the unknown mechanics of the atom
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding scientific concepts is distilling a pure substance

metaphors.Full Sentence: The art of guessing correct formulae, which deviate from the classical formulae, yet contain them as a limiting case according to the correspondence principle, was brought to a high degree of perfection.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: The art of guessing correct formulae
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific discovery is an art

paradoxes.full_sentence: The logical difficulty became ever sharper. Investigations into the scattering and dispersion of light showed that Einstein’s conception of transition probability as a measure of the strength of an oscillation did not meet the case, and the idea of an amplitude of oscillation associated with each transition was indispensable.
terms_in_conflict: amplitude of oscillation associated with each transition
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the conflict between Einstein's conception of transition probability as a measure of the strength of an oscillation and the indispensable idea of an amplitude of oscillation associated with each transition. The two concepts seem to contradict each other, creating a logical difficulty.

paradoxes.full_sentence: The art of guessing correct formulae, which deviate from the classical formulae, yet contain them as a limiting case according to the correspondence principle, was brought to a high degree of perfection.
terms_in_conflict: contain them as a limiting case according to the correspondence principle
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is the tension between the deviation from classical formulae and the inclusion of these formulae as a limiting case according to the correspondence principle. The two concepts seem to be in conflict, as deviation implies difference, while inclusion as a limiting case implies a certain level of similarity or continuity.

paragraph:
Heisenberg, who at that time was my assistant, brought this period to a
sudden end’. He cut the Gordian knot by means of a philosophical prin-

metaphors.Full sentence: Heisenberg, who at that time was my assistant, brought this period to a sudden end'. He cut the Gordian knot by means of a philosophical prin-
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: He cut the Gordian knot

paragraph:
ciple and replaced guess-work by a mathematical rule. The principle states
that concepts and representations that do not correspond to physically ob-
servable facts are not to be used in theoretical description. Einstein used the

metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: concepts and representations that do not correspond to physically observable facts
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Concepts and representations are like physically observable facts

paragraph:
--- Page 4 ---
INTERPRETATION OF QUANTUM MECHANICS 259

same principle when, in setting up his theory of relativity, he eliminated the
concepts of absolute velocity of a body and of absolute simultaneity of two
events at different places. Heisenberg banished the picture of electron orbits
with definite radii and periods of rotation because these quantities are not
observable, and insisted that the theory be built up by means of the square
arrays mentioned above. Instead of describing the motion by giving a co-
ordinate as a function of time, x(¢), an array of transition amplitudes Xn
should be determined. To me the decisive part of his work is the demand
to determine a rule by which from a given

paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the conflict between the traditional understanding of electron orbits with definite properties and Heisenberg's insistence on using unobservable quantities to build up the theory.

paragraph: array | X21 X22 .---+-s the array for the square | (x*)2; (x@)22 ...--
can be found (or, more general, the multiplication rule for such arrays).

By observation of known examples solved by guess-work he found this
tule and applied it successfully to simple examples such as the harmonic and
anharmonic oscillator.

This was in the summer of 1925. Heisenberg, plagued by hay fever took
leave for a course of treatment by the sea and gave me his paper for publica-
tion if I thought I could do something with it.

The significance of the idea was at once clear to me and I sent the manu-
script to the Zeitschrift fiir Physik. I could not take my mind off Heisenberg’s
multiplication rule, and after a week of intensive thought and trial I suddenly
remembered an algebraic theory which I had learned from my teacher,
Professor Rosanes, in Breslau. Such square arrays are well known to math-
ematicians and, in conjunction with a specific rule for multiplication, are
called matrices. I applied this rule to Heisenberg’s quantum condition and
found that this agreed in the diagonal terms. It was easy to guess what the
remaining quantities must be, namely, zero; and at once there stood before
me the peculiar formula

metaphors.Full sentence: and at once there stood before me the peculiar formula
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: there stood before me the peculiar formula
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding a concept is like seeing an object

metaphors.Full sentence: It was easy to guess what the remaining quantities must be, namely, zero
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: It was easy to guess
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding a scientific concept is like guessing a result

paradoxes.full_sentence: I applied this rule to Heisenberg’s quantum condition and found that this agreed in the diagonal terms.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox arises from the application of a mathematical rule (multiplication) to a quantum condition. In quantum physics, multiplication doesn't always follow the traditional rules of mathematics, leading to a conceptual tension.

paradoxes.full_sentence: It was easy to guess what the remaining quantities must be, namely, zero; and at once there stood before me the peculiar formula
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the tension between the ease of guessing the remaining quantities and the resulting peculiar formula. The simplicity of the guess contrasts with the complexity of the resulting formula.

paragraph:
This meant that coordinates q and momenta p cannot be represented by
figure values but by symbols, the product of which depends upon the order
of multiplication - they are said to be « non-commuting ».

I was as excited by this result as a sailor would be who, after a long voyage,
sees from afar, the longed-for land, and I felt regret that Heisenberg was not

metaphors.Full sentence: I was as excited by this result as a sailor would be who, after a long voyage, sees from afar, the longed-for land
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: as excited by this result as a sailor would be who, after a long voyage, sees from afar, the longed-for land
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific discovery is a long voyage

paragraph:
there. I was convinced from the start that we had stumbled on the right path.
Even so, a great part was only guess-work, in particular, the disappearance
of the non-diagonal elements in the above-mentioned expression. For help
in this problem I obtained the assistance and collaboration of my pupil
Pascual Jordan, and in a few days we were able to demonstrate that I had
guessed correctly. The joint paper by Jordan and myself* contains the most
important principles of quantum mechanics including its extension to elec-
trodynamics. There followed a hectic period of collaboration among the
three of us, complicated by Heisenberg’s absence. There was a lively ex-
change of letters; my contribution to these, unfortunately, have been lost in
the political disorders. The result was a three-author paper’ which brought
the formal side of the investigation to a definite conclusion. Before this paper
appeared, came the first dramatic surprise: Paul Dirac’s paper on the same
subject’. The inspiration afforded by a lecture of Heisenberg’s in Cambridge
had led him to similar results as we had obtained in Géttingen except that
he did not resort to the known matrix theory of the mathematicians, but
discovered the tool for himself and worked out the theory of such non-
commutating symbols.

paragraph:
The first non-trivial and physically important application of quantum
mechanics was made shortly afterwards by W. Pauli’'who calculated the
stationary energy values of the hydrogen atom by means of the matrix method
and found complete agreement with Bohr’s formulae. From this moment
onwards there could no longer be any doubt about the correctness of the
theory.

metaphors.Full sentence: From this moment onwards there could no longer be any doubt about the correctness of the theory.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: no longer be any doubt
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Doubt is an obstacle

paragraph:
What this formalism really signified was, however, by no means clear.
Mathematics, as often happens, was cleverer than interpretative thought.
While we were still discussing this point there came the second dramatic
surprise, the appearance of Schrédinger’s famous papers”. He took up quite
a different line of thought which had originated from Louis de Broglie”.

metaphors.Full sentence: Mathematics, as often happens, was cleverer than interpretative thought.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: Mathematics, as often happens, was cleverer than interpretative thought.
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Mathematics is a clever being

metaphors.Full sentence: While we were still discussing this point there came the second dramatic surprise, the appearance of Schrédinger’s famous papers.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: there came the second dramatic surprise, the appearance of Schrédinger’s famous papers.
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Discovering new scientific papers is like experiencing a dramatic surprise

metaphors.Full sentence: He took up quite a different line of thought which had originated from Louis de Broglie.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: He took up quite a different line of thought
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Thinking is following a line

paragraph:
A few years previously, the latter had made the bold assertion, supported
by brilliant theoretical considerations, that wave-corpuscle duality, familiar
to physicists in the case of light, must also be valid for electrons. To each
electron moving free of force belongs a plane wave of a definite wavelength
which is determined by Planck’s constant and the mass. This exciting disser-
tation by De Broglie was well known to us in Géttingen. One day in
1925 I received a letter from C. J. Davisson giving some peculiar results on
the reflection of electrons from metallic surfaces. I, and my colleague on the
experimental side, James Franck, at once suspected that these curves of

metaphors.Full sentence: A few years previously, the latter had made the bold assertion, supported by brilliant theoretical considerations, that wave-corpuscle duality, familiar to physicists in the case of light, must also be valid for electrons.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: made the bold assertion
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Asserting a theory is like making a bold move

metaphors.Full sentence: To each electron moving free of force belongs a plane wave of a definite wavelength which is determined by Planck’s constant and the mass.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: electron moving free of force belongs a plane wave
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Electrons are like entities that possess things

metaphors.Full sentence: This exciting dissertation by De Broglie was well known to us in Géttingen.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: exciting dissertation
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Dissertations are like thrilling events

metaphors.Full sentence: One day in 1925 I received a letter from C. J. Davisson giving some peculiar results on the reflection of electrons from metallic surfaces.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: peculiar results
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific results are like surprising discoveries

paradoxes.full_sentence: A few years previously, the latter had made the bold assertion, supported by brilliant theoretical considerations, that wave-corpuscle duality, familiar to physicists in the case of light, must also be valid for electrons.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the application of wave-corpuscle duality, which is a concept traditionally associated with light, to electrons. This presents a conceptual tension as it challenges the traditional understanding of electrons as particles, suggesting instead that they also exhibit wave-like properties.

paragraph:
--- Page 6 ---
INTERPRETATION OF QUANTUM MECHANICS 261

Davisson’s were crystal-lattice spectra of De Broglie’s electron waves, and
we made one of our pupils, Elsasser'’, to investigate the matter. His result
provided the first preliminary confirmation of the idea of De Broglie’s, and
this was later proved independently by Davisson and Germer’ and G. P.
Thomson" by systematic experiments.

But this acquaintance with De Broglie’s way of thinking did not lead us
to an attempt to apply it to the electronic structure in atoms. This was left
to Schrédinger. He extended De Broglie’s wave equation which referred to
force-free motion, to the case where the effect of force is taken into account,
and gave an exact formulation of the subsidiary conditions, already suggested
by De Broglie, to which the wave function y must be subjected, namely that
it should be single-valued and finite in space and time. And he was successful
in deriving the stationary states of the hydrogen atom in the form of those
monochromatic solutions of his wave equation which do not extend to
infinity.

metaphors.Full sentence: But this acquaintance with De Broglie’s way of thinking did not lead us to an attempt to apply it to the electronic structure in atoms.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: acquaintance with De Broglie’s way of thinking
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding a theory is being acquainted with a person's way of thinking

metaphors.Full sentence: He extended De Broglie’s wave equation which referred to force-free motion, to the case where the effect of force is taken into account
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: extended De Broglie’s wave equation
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Developing a theory further is extending it

metaphors.Full sentence: And he was successful in deriving the stationary states of the hydrogen atom in the form of those monochromatic solutions of his wave equation which do not extend to infinity.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: monochromatic solutions of his wave equation
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Solutions to a scientific problem are colors in a spectrum

paragraph:
For a brief period at the beginning of 1926, it looked as though there
were, suddenly, two self-contained but quite distinct systems of explanation
extant: matrix mechanics and wave mechanics. But Schrédinger himself
soon demonstrated their complete equivalence.

metaphors.Full sentence: But Schrédinger himself soon demonstrated their complete equivalence.

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Theoritical congruence is equivalence

paradoxes.full_sentence: For a brief period at the beginning of 1926, it looked as though there were, suddenly, two self-contained but quite distinct systems of explanation extant: matrix mechanics and wave mechanics.
terms_in_conflict: two self-contained but quite distinct systems of explanation
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the fact that two distinct systems of explanation, matrix mechanics and wave mechanics, are presented as self-contained yet different, implying they cannot be reconciled.

paradoxes.full_sentence: But Schrédinger himself soon demonstrated their complete equivalence.
terms_in_conflict: two self-contained but quite distinct systems of explanation
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox is resolved when Schrédinger demonstrates that the two distinct systems of explanation, previously thought to be irreconcilable, are in fact completely equivalent.

paragraph:
Wave mechanics enjoyed a very great deal more popularity than the
Géttingen or Cambridge version of quantum mechanics. It operates with a
wave function y, which in the case of one particle at least, can be pictured
in space, and it uses the mathematical methods of partial differential equations
which are in current use by physicists. Schrédinger thought that his wave
theory made it possible to return to deterministic classical physics. He propos-
ed (and he has recently emphasized his proposal anew’s), to dispense with the
particle representation entirely, and instead of speaking of electrons as par-
ticles, to consider them as a continuous density distribution ipl (or electric
density e|y/).

metaphors.Full sentence: Wave mechanics enjoyed a very great deal more popularity than the Géttingen or Cambridge version of quantum mechanics.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: Wave mechanics enjoyed a very great deal more popularity
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific theories are like people who can enjoy popularity.

metaphors.Full sentence: Schrédinger thought that his wave theory made it possible to return to deterministic classical physics.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: return to deterministic classical physics
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The process of scientific discovery is likened to a journey where one can return to a previous location (i.e., previous scientific paradigm).

metaphors.Full sentence: He proposed (and he has recently emphasized his proposal anew’s), to dispense with the particle representation entirely, and instead of speaking of electrons as particles, to consider them as a continuous density distribution ipl (or electric density e|y/).
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: speaking of electrons as particles
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Electrons, abstract entities, are spoken of as if they were concrete particles that one can speak about.

paradoxes.Full sentence: Schrédinger thought that his wave theory made it possible to return to deterministic classical physics.
paradoxes.Short explanation of the paradox: Wave theory, as part of quantum mechanics, is inherently probabilistic and not deterministic. This is in conflict with the deterministic nature of classical physics, where outcomes can be precisely predicted. Schrödinger's belief that his wave theory could return physics to determinism is paradoxical.

paradoxes.Full sentence: He proposed (and he has recently emphasized his proposal anew’s), to dispense with the particle representation entirely, and instead of speaking of electrons as particles, to consider them as a continuous density distribution ipl (or electric density e|y/).
paradoxes.Short explanation of the paradox: The paradox lies in the conceptual conflict between treating electrons as discrete particles versus treating them as a continuous density distribution. These are fundamentally different ways of understanding the nature of electrons, and it's paradoxical to propose that one could simply switch from one to the other.

paragraph:
To us in Géttingen this interpretation seemed unacceptable in face of
well established experimental facts. At that time it was already possible to
count particles by means of scintillations or with a Geiger counter, and to
photograph their tracks with the aid of a Wilson cloud chamber.

It appeared to me that it was not possible to obtain a clear interpretation
of the y-function, by considering bound electrons. I had therefore, as early
as the end of 1925, made an attempt to extend the matrix method, which
obviously only covered oscillatory processes, in such a way as to be
applicable to aperiodic processes. I was at that time a guest of the Mas-

sachusetts Institute of Technology in the USA, and I found there in Norbert
Wiener an excellent collaborator. In our joint paper we replaced the
matrix by the general concept of an operator, and thus made it possible to
describe aperiodic processes. Nevertheless we missed the correct approach.
This was left to Schrédinger, and I immediately took up his method since it
held promise of leading to an interpretation of the yfunction. Again an idea
of Einstein’s gave me the lead. He had tried to make the duality of particles -
light quanta or photons - and waves comprehensible by interpreting the
square of the optical wave amplitudes as probability density for the occur-
rence of photons. This concept could at once be carried over to the yfunc-
tion: |y? ought to represent the probability density for electrons (or other
particles). It was easy to assert this, but how could it be proved?

metaphors.Full sentence: Again an idea of Einstein’s gave me the lead.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: gave me the lead
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Idea is a guide

metaphors.Full sentence: This was left to Schrédinger, and I immediately took up his method since it held promise of leading to an interpretation of the yfunction.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: held promise of leading
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Method is a path

metaphors.Full sentence: This concept could at once be carried over to the yfunction
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: carried over
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Applying a concept is a movement of carrying

paragraph:
The atomic collision processes suggested themselves at this point. A swarm
of electrons coming from infinity, represented by an incident wave of
known intensity (i.e., yy), impinges upon an obstacle, say a heavy atom.
In the same way that a water wave produced by a steamer causes secondary
circular waves in striking a pile, the incident electron wave is partially
transformed into a secondary spherical wave whose amplitude of oscillation
y differs for different directions. The square of the amplitude of this wave at
a great distance from the scattering centre determines the relative probability
of scattering as a function of direction. Moreover, if the scattering atom it-
self is capable of existing in different stationary states, then Schrédinger’s
wave equation gives automatically the probability of excitation of these
states, the electron being scattered with loss of energy, that is to say, inelastic-
ally, as it is called. In this way it was possible to get a theoretical basis” for
the assumptions of Bohr’s theory which had been experimentally confirmed
by Franck and Hertz. Soon Wentzel" succeeded in deriving Rutherford’s
amous formula for the scattering of o-particles from my theory.

metaphors.Full sentence: A swarm of electrons coming from infinity, represented by an incident wave of known intensity (i.e., yy), impinges upon an obstacle, say a heavy atom.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: A swarm of electrons coming from infinity
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Electrons are depicted as a swarm (group of insects) coming from infinity

metaphors.Full sentence: In the same way that a water wave produced by a steamer causes secondary circular waves in striking a pile, the incident electron wave is partially transformed into a secondary spherical wave whose amplitude of oscillation y differs for different directions.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: In the same way that a water wave produced by a steamer causes secondary circular waves in striking a pile
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Electron wave is compared to a water wave caused by a steamer

metaphors.Full sentence: The square of the amplitude of this wave at a great distance from the scattering centre determines the relative probability of scattering as a function of direction.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: at a great distance from the scattering centre
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The electron's position relative to the scattering center is depicted as a great distance

metaphors.Full sentence: Moreover, if the scattering atom itself is capable of existing in different stationary states, then Schrédinger’s wave equation gives automatically the probability of excitation of these states, the electron being scattered with loss of energy, that is to say, inelastically, as it is called.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: the electron being scattered with loss of energy
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Electron scattering is described in terms of energy loss

paragraph:
However, a paper by Heisenberg”, containing his celebrated uncertainty
relationship, contributed more than the above-mentioned successes to the
swift acceptance of the statistical interpretation of the ywfunction. It was
hrough this paper that the revolutionary character of the new conception
became clear. It showed that not only the determinism of classical physics
must be abandonded, but also the naive concept of reality which looked upon
the particles of atomic physics as if they were very small grains of sand. At
every instant a grain of sand has a definite position and velocity. This is not
he case with an electron. If its position is determined with increasing ac-

metaphors.Full sentence: It showed that not only the determinism of classical physics must be abandonded, but also the naive concept of reality which looked upon the particles of atomic physics as if they were very small grains of sand.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: looked upon the particles of atomic physics as if they were very small grains of sand
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Particles of atomic physics are compared to very small grains of sand

paradoxes.full_sentence: It showed that not only the determinism of classical physics must be abandonded, but also the naive concept of reality which looked upon the particles of atomic physics as if they were very small grains of sand.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the conflict between the deterministic nature of classical physics, which assumes that every event is determined by its preceding conditions, and the concept of reality in quantum physics, which suggests that particles do not have definite positions and velocities like classical objects (e.g., grains of sand).

versa. Ishall return shortly to these problems in a more general connection,
but would first like to say a few words about the theory of collisions.
The mathematical approximation methods which I used were quite prim-
itive and soon improved upon. From the literature, which has grown to a
point where I cannot cope with, I would like to mention only a few of
he first authors to whom the theory owes great progress: Faxén in

Sweden, Holtsmark in Norway”, Bethe in Germany”, Mott and Massey
in England*.
Today, collision theory is a special science with its own big, solid text-
books which have grown completely over my head. Of course in the last
resort all the modern branches of physics, quantum electrodynamics, the
heory of mesons, nuclei, cosmic rays, elementary particles and their trans-
‘ormations, all come within range of these ideas and no bounds could be set
0 a discussion on them.

paragraph:
Ishould also like to mention that in 1926 and 1927 I tried another way of
supporting the statistical concept of quantum mechanics, partly in collabora-
ion with the Russian physicist Fock**. In the above-mentioned three-

author paper there is a chapter which anticipates the Schrédinger function,
except that it is not thought of as a function p(x) in space, but as a function
Wn of the discrete index n = 1, 2,... which enumerates the stationary states.
If the system under consideration is subject to a force which is variable with
time, yn becomes also time-dependent, and | yp (t) |? signifies the prob-
ability for the existence of the state n at time f. Starting from an initial
distribution where there is only one state, transition probabilities are ob-
tained, and their properties can be examined. What interested me in partic-
ular at the time, was what occurs in the adiabatic limiting case, that is, for
very slowly changing action. It was possible to show that, as could have been
expected, the probability of transitions becomes ever smaller. The theory of
transition probabilities was developed independently by Dirac with great
success. It can be said that the whole of atomic and nuclear physics works
with this system of concepts, particularly in the very elegant form given to

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The force is a changing environment

metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific field is a labourer

paragraph:
them by Dirac**. Almost all experiments lead to statements about relative
frequencies of events, even when they occur concealed under such names as
effective cross section or the like.

How does it come about then, that great scientists such as Einstein, Schré-
dinger, and De Broglie are nevertheless dissatisfied with the situation? Of
course, all these objections are levelled not against the correctness of the
formulae, but against their interpretation. Two closely knitted points of view

metaphors.Full sentence: Two closely knitted points of view
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: closely knitted
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Ideas are physical objects that can be knitted together

paragraph: are to be distinguished: the question of determinism and the question of reality.
Newtonian mechanics is deterministic in the following sense:

If the initial state (positions and velocities of all particles) of a system is
accurately given, then the state at any other time (earlier or later) can be
calculated from the laws of mechanics. All the other branches of classical
physics have been built up according to this model. Mechanical determinism
gradually became a kind of article of faith: the world as a machine, an
automaton. As far as I can see, this idea has no forerunners in ancient and
medieval philosophy. The idea is a product of the immense success of
Newtonian mechanics, particularly in astronomy. In the 19th century it be-
came a basic philosophical principle for the whole of exact science. I asked
myself whether this was really justified. Can absolute predictions really be
made for all time on the basis of the classical equations of motion? It can
easily be seen, by simple examples, that this is only the case when the
possibility of absolutely exact measurement (of position, velocity, or other
quantities) is assumed. Let us think of a particle moving without friction on
a straight line between two end-points (walls), at which it experiences com-
pletely elastic recoil. It moves with constant speed equal to its initial speed
v backwards and forwards, and it can be stated exactly where it will be at
a given time provided that v,is accurately known. But if a small inaccuracy
Av, is allowed, then the inaccuracy of prediction of the position at time t is
t Av, which increases with t. If one waits long enough until time f= Avo
where | is the distance between the elastic walls, the inaccuracy 4x will have
become equal to the whole space /. Thus it is impossible to forecast anything
about the position at a time which is later than t,. Thus determinism lapses
completely into indeterminism as soon as the slightest inaccuracy in the data
on velocity is permitted. Is there any sense - and I mean any physical sense,
not metaphysical sense - in which one can speak of absolute data? Is one
justified in saying that the coordinate x = mcm where nm = 3.1415. . is the
familiar transcendental number that determines the ratio of the circumfer-
ence of a circle to its diameter? As a mathematical tool the concept of a real
number represented by a nonterminating decimal fraction is exceptionally
important and fruitful. As the measure of a physical quantity it is nonsense. If
mis taken to the 20th or the 25th place of decimals, two numbers are ob-
tained which are indistinguishable from each other and the true value of 7
by any measurement. According to the heuristic principle used by Einstein
in the theory of relativity, and by Heisenberg in the quantum theory, con-
cepts which correspond to no conceivable observation should be eliminated

metaphors.Full sentence: Mechanical determinism gradually became a kind of article of faith: the world as a machine, an automaton.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: the world as a machine, an automaton
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: The world is modeled as a mechanical system, with consistent, predictable movements and interactions

metaphors.Full sentence: Thus determinism lapses completely into indeterminism as soon as the slightest inaccuracy in the data on velocity is permitted.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: determinism lapses completely into indeterminism
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Determinism and Indeterminism are portrayed as states that can be transitioned between, like physical locations or statuses

paradoxes.full_sentence: If the initial state (positions and velocities of all particles) of a system is accurately given, then the state at any other time (earlier or later) can be calculated from the laws of mechanics.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the assumption that if the initial state of a system is known, the state at any other time can be calculated. However, this assumes perfect knowledge and measurement, which is not possible in reality.

paradoxes.full_sentence: Thus determinism lapses completely into indeterminism as soon as the slightest inaccuracy in the data on velocity is permitted.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that the deterministic model of physics, which assumes that the future state of a system can be predicted from its current state, lapses into indeterminism as soon as any inaccuracy is allowed. This contradicts the deterministic model.

paradoxes.full_sentence: As the measure of a physical quantity it is nonsense.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that while nonterminating decimal fractions are useful as mathematical tools, they are nonsensical when used to measure physical quantities. This is because physical measurements cannot be infinitely precise.

paragraph:
--- Page 10 ---
INTERPRETATION OF QUANTUM MECHANICS 265

from physics. This is possible without difficulty in the present case also. It is
only necessary to replace statements like x = cm by: the probability of
distribution of values of x has a sharp maximum at x = mcm, and (if it is
desired to be more accurate) to add: of such and such a breadth. In short,
ordinary mechanics must also be statistically formulated. I have occupied
myself with this problem a little recently, and have realized that it is pos-
sible without difficulty. This is not the place to go into the matter more
deeply. Ishould like only to say this: the determinism of classical physics
turns out to be an illusion, created by overrating mathematico-logical con-
cepts. It is an idol, not an ideal in scientific research and cannot, therefore,
be used as an objection to the essentially indeterministic statistical interpre-
tation of quantum mechanics.

metaphors.Full Sentence: I should like only to say this: the determinism of classical physics turns out to be an illusion, created by overrating mathematico-logical concepts.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: the determinism of classical physics turns out to be an illusion
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Determinism is an illusion

metaphors.Full Sentence: It is an idol, not an ideal in scientific research and cannot, therefore, be used as an objection to the essentially indeterministic statistical interpretation of quantum mechanics.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: It is an idol, not an ideal in scientific research
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Determinism is an idol

paradoxes.full_sentence: Ishould like only to say this: the determinism of classical physics turns out to be an illusion, created by overrating mathematico-logical concepts.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the assertion that the determinism of classical physics, which is a fundamental principle stating that the state of the universe at any given time is a direct result of its state at all previous times, is an illusion. This contradicts the basic understanding of classical physics.

paradoxes.full_sentence: It is an idol, not an ideal in scientific research and cannot, therefore, be used as an objection to the essentially indeterministic statistical interpretation of quantum mechanics.
terms_in_conflict: Indeterministic statistical interpretation of quantum mechanics
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that the deterministic nature of classical physics, which is revered ('idol') in scientific research, is being contrasted with the indeterministic nature of quantum mechanics. This presents a paradox as it challenges the traditional deterministic understanding of physics.

paragraph: Much more difficult is the objection based on reality. The concept of a

particle, e.g. a grain of sand, implicitly contains the idea that it is in a definite
position and has definite motion. But according to quantum mechanics it
is impossible to determine simultaneously with any desired accuracy both
position and velocity (more precisely : momentum, i.e. mass times velocity) .
Thus two questions arise: what prevents us, in spite of the theoretical asser-
tion, to measure both quantities to any desired degree of accuracy by refined
experiments? Secondly, if it really transpires that this is not feasible, are we
still justified in applying to the electron the concept of particle and therefore
the ideas associated with it?

metaphors.Full Sentence: particle, e.g. a grain of sand, implicitly contains the idea that it is in a definite position and has definite motion.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: a grain of sand
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Particle is a grain of sand

metaphors.Full Sentence: what prevents us, in spite of the theoretical assertion, to measure both quantities to any desired degree of accuracy by refined experiments?
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: refined experiments
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Experiment is a refining process

paradoxes.full_sentence: particle, e.g. a grain of sand, implicitly contains the idea that it is in a definite position and has definite motion. But according to quantum mechanics it is impossible to determine simultaneously with any desired accuracy both position and velocity (more precisely : momentum, i.e. mass times velocity).
paradoxes.explanation: The concept of a 'particle' implies a definite position and motion, but quantum mechanics states that it's impossible to accurately determine both position and velocity at the same time. This creates a paradox between the traditional understanding of a particle and the quantum mechanical understanding.

paradoxes.full_sentence: Secondly, if it really transpires that this is not feasible, are we still justified in applying to the electron the concept of particle and therefore the ideas associated with it?
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is whether we can still consider an electron as a 'particle' if we cannot accurately determine its position and velocity simultaneously, as the concept of a particle implies.

paragraph:
Referring to the first question, it is clear that if the theory is correct - and
we have ample grounds for believing this - the obstacle to simultaneous
measurement of position and motion (and of other such pairs of so-called
conjugate quantities) must lie in the laws of quantum mechanics themselves.
In fact, this is so. But it is not a simple matter to clarify the situation. Niels
Bohr himself has gone to great trouble and ingenuity” to develop a theory
of measurements to clear the matter up and to meet the most refined and
ingenious attacks of Einstein, who repeatedly tried to think out methods of
measurement by means of which position and motion could be measured
simultaneously and accurately. The following emerges: to measure space
coordinates and instants of time, rigid measuring rods and clocks are re-
quired. On the other hand, to measure momenta and energies, devices are
necessary with movable parts to absorb the impact of the test object and to
indicate the size of its momentum. Paying regard to the fact that quantum
mechanics is competent for dealing with the interaction of object and appa-
ratus, it is seen that no arrangement is possible that will fulfil both require-

metaphors.Full Sentence: Niels Bohr himself has gone to great trouble and ingenuity to develop a theory of measurements to clear the matter up and to meet the most refined and ingenious attacks of Einstein, who repeatedly tried to think out methods of measurement by means of which position and motion could be measured simultaneously and accurately.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: Niels Bohr himself has gone to great trouble and ingenuity
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Effort and ingenuity in scientific theory development is a difficult journey

metaphors.Full Sentence: Niels Bohr himself has gone to great trouble and ingenuity to develop a theory of measurements to clear the matter up and to meet the most refined and ingenious attacks of Einstein, who repeatedly tried to think out methods of measurement by means of which position and motion could be measured simultaneously and accurately.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: to meet the most refined and ingenious attacks of Einstein
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific debate and criticism is a battle

metaphors.Full Sentence: On the other hand, to measure momenta and energies, devices are necessary with movable parts to absorb the impact of the test object and to indicate the size of its momentum.
metaphors.Metaphorical Phrase: devices are necessary with movable parts to absorb the impact of the test object and to indicate the size of its momentum
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific devices are sentient beings that absorb and indicate

paradoxes.full_sentence: Referring to the first question, it is clear that if the theory is correct - and we have ample grounds for believing this - the obstacle to simultaneous measurement of position and motion (and of other such pairs of so-called conjugate quantities) must lie in the laws of quantum mechanics themselves.
terms_in_conflict: simultaneous measurement of position and motion
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the fact that the theory, which is believed to be correct, inherently prevents the simultaneous measurement of position and motion, a task that one would expect to be possible if the theory is indeed correct.

paradoxes.full_sentence: The following emerges: to measure space coordinates and instants of time, rigid measuring rods and clocks are required. On the other hand, to measure momenta and energies, devices are necessary with movable parts to absorb the impact of the test object and to indicate the size of its momentum.
terms_in_conflict: measure space coordinates and instants of time
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox here is that to measure different aspects of the same system (space-time coordinates and momenta-energies), fundamentally different types of measurement devices are required - rigid for the former and movable for the latter. This creates a tension in the practical application of the theory.

paragraph:
ments simultaneously. There exist, therefore, mutually exclusive though
complementary experiments which only as a whole embrace everything
which can be experienced with regard to an object.

metaphors.Full sentence: There exist, therefore, mutually exclusive though complementary experiments which only as a whole embrace everything which can be experienced with regard to an object.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: experiments which only as a whole embrace everything
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Experiments are like arms that can embrace

paradoxes.full_sentence: There exist, therefore, mutually exclusive though complementary experiments which only as a whole embrace everything which can be experienced with regard to an object.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the idea that experiments can be both mutually exclusive (cannot occur at the same time or in the same context) and complementary (each adding something the others lack, thus together providing a complete picture). This suggests a tension between the need for distinct, separate experiments and the need for a comprehensive understanding of an object.

paragraph:
This idea of complementarity is now regarded by most physicists as the
key to the clear understanding of quantum processes. Bohr has generalized
the idea to quite different fields of knowledge, e.g. the connection be-
tween consciousness and the brain, to the problem of free will, and other
basic problems of philosophy. To come now to the last point: can we call
something with which the concepts of position and motion cannot be asso-
ciated in the usual way, a thing, or a particle? And if not, what is the reality
which our theory has been invented to describe?

metaphors.Full sentence: This idea of complementarity is now regarded by most physicists as the key to the clear understanding of quantum processes.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: key to the clear understanding
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding is unlocking

metaphors.Full sentence: And if not, what is the reality which our theory has been invented to describe?
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: our theory has been invented to describe
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Theory is an invention

paradoxes.full_sentence: To come now to the last point: can we call something with which the concepts of position and motion cannot be associated in the usual way, a thing, or a particle?
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the question of whether an entity can be considered a 'thing' or 'particle' if it does not conform to the traditional concepts of position and motion, as is the case in quantum physics. This challenges our conventional understanding of reality.

paradoxes.full_sentence: And if not, what is the reality which our theory has been invented to describe?
paradoxes.explanation: This question presents a paradox by suggesting that our theories, designed to describe reality, may not be able to accurately represent it if the entities they describe do not conform to traditional concepts.

paragraph:
The answer to this is no longer physics, but philosophy, and to deal with
it thoroughly would mean going far beyond the bounds of this lecture. I
have given my views on it elsewhere **. Here I will only say that I am em-
phatically in favour of the retention of the particle idea. Naturally, it is
necessary to redefine what is meant. For this, well-developed concepts are
available which appear in mathematics under the name of invariants in trans-
formations. Every object that we perceive appears in innumerable aspects.
The concept of the object is the invariant of all these aspects. From this point
of view, the present universally used system of concepts in which particles
and waves appear simultaneously, can be completely justified.

metaphors.Full sentence: The concept of the object is the invariant of all these aspects.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: The concept of the object is the invariant of all these aspects.
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Concept is an invariant

metaphors.Full sentence: From this point of view, the present universally used system of concepts in which particles and waves appear simultaneously, can be completely justified.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: particles and waves appear simultaneously
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific concepts are physical entities

paradoxes.full_sentence: From this point of view, the present universally used system of concepts in which particles and waves appear simultaneously, can be completely justified.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the simultaneous existence of particles and waves in the same system. In classical physics, these are distinct concepts - particles are discrete, localized entities, while waves are continuous and spread out. The author acknowledges this paradox, but suggests it can be resolved by redefining our understanding of these concepts.

paragraph:
The latest research on nuclei and elementary particles has led us, how-
ever, to limits beyond which this system of concepts itself does not appear to
suffice. The lesson to be learned from what I have told of the origin of
quantum mechanics is that probable refinements of mathematical methods
will not suffice to produce a satisfactory theory, but that somewhere in our
doctrine is hidden a concept, unjustified by experience, which we must elim-
inate to open up the road.

metaphors.Full sentence: The latest research on nuclei and elementary particles has led us, however, to limits beyond which this system of concepts itself does not appear to suffice.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: limits beyond which this system of concepts itself does not appear to suffice
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Understanding is a journey

metaphors.Full sentence: The lesson to be learned from what I have told of the origin of quantum mechanics is that probable refinements of mathematical methods will not suffice to produce a satisfactory theory, but that somewhere in our doctrine is hidden a concept, unjustified by experience, which we must eliminate to open up the road.
metaphors.Metaphorical phrase: somewhere in our doctrine is hidden a concept, unjustified by experience, which we must eliminate to open up the road
metaphors.Conceptual Mapping: Scientific progress is a road

paradoxes.full_sentence: The lesson to be learned from what I have told of the origin of quantum mechanics is that probable refinements of mathematical methods will not suffice to produce a satisfactory theory, but that somewhere in our doctrine is hidden a concept, unjustified by experience, which we must eliminate to open up the road.
paradoxes.explanation: The paradox lies in the idea that while scientific theories are often refined and improved through mathematical methods, the author suggests that in the case of quantum mechanics, this approach is insufficient. Instead, they propose that there is a concept, not justified by experience, that needs to be eliminated. This presents a tension between the traditional scientific method of refining theories through mathematics and the need to eliminate unjustified concepts.
